title: VC Daily: Draper Esprit Move May Give Retail Investors Startup Exposure
text:
The move comes on the heels of a spectacular first half for venture capital in Europe, with funding to startups setting a new record and valuations climbing, according to PitchBook Data Inc . IPO activity in London ground to a near-halt in 2020, but the London Stock Exchange is once again hosting high-profile initial public offerings, among them the recent listings of food delivery app Deliveroo Holdings PLC and cybersecurity company Darktrace PLC . In the first six months of this year, venture-backed startups raised more than $20 billion through London listings, compared with around $1 billion in all of last year, PitchBook data show.

Based in London, Draper Esprit has gained both as a company and as a stock from the private-market frenzy. Bets on high-flyers like Revolut Ltd ., Trustpilot Inc . and UiPath Inc . have raised the value of its portfolio to almost $1.4 billion from roughly $100 million in the early days of its 2006 founding. Draper Espirit's market cap stands at more than $2.1 billion.

As a public company, Draper Esprit can offer founders access to institutional investors that buy stocks and that could help usher their brainchildren to the public markets, said Chief Executive Martin Davis .

"A lot of the entrepreneurs see us as almost like an early dating agency with some of these public-market investors," Mr. Davis said.

And now on to the news...

Top News

New fund. Foothill Ventures, a seed-stage venture-capital firm previously named Tsingyuan Ventures, has raised a $100 million fund that it will use to double down on its strategy of investing in North American startups founded by immigrant entrepreneurs, WSJ Pro's Marc Vartabedian reports.

The Los Altos, Calif.-based firm said the strategy allows it to capitalize on technical talent that has been overlooked by many mainstream Silicon Valley investors.

Roughly 84% of the startups in Foothill's portfolio were launched by immigrants and include technology companies in fields such as medical imaging and autonomous vehicle radar.

Foothill believes immigrant founders haven't received the same level of investment from traditional venture firms as other founders because of cultural mismatches, Managing Partner Eric Rosenblum said.

FullStory Raises $103 Million, Valuing It at $1.8 Billion

FullStory Inc., which uses data and analytics to help its clients retain and build customer relationships, raised $103 million in new funding that values the company at $1.8 billion, WSJ Pro's Laura Cooper reports.

Private-equity firm Permira Advisers LLC led the round out of its growth opportunities strategy, which focuses on smaller investments in companies than the firm typically backs out of its main private-equity funds. All of the company's existing investors also participated in the round, among them Kleiner Perkins , GV (formerly Google Ventures ), Stripes LLC , Dell Technologies Capital, Salesforce Ventures and Glynn Capital.

As SPAC Creators Get Rich, How Incentives Are Shared Remains Murky

Many investment executives who back special-purpose acquisition companies are scoring big paydays as more deals get completed. Some of their clients are missing out, The Wall Street Journal reports. The divergence results from the varying methods SPAC creators use to share the lucrative incentives known as the "sponsor promote." It typically consists of deeply discounted shares and other securities executives receive for risking capital to set up the SPAC and vet a company to take public. The promote typically allows creators to make tens of millions of dollars on paper on average—sometimes several times their initial investment—even if that company's shares fall.

$46.80

Price per share reached by Robinhood's stock in Tuesday's session, a reversal from an underwhelming trading debut last week. (WSJ)

Industry News

Funds

Moderne Ventures closed an oversubscribed $200 million second fund, bringing the firm's total assets under management to nearly $350 million. The Chicago-based firm invests in real estate, finance, insurance and home services.

London-based Element Ventures closed a $130 million inaugural fund to make Series A and B investments in enterprise financial technology startups across Europe, the U.S. and Asia. The firm aims to invest in 15 portfolio companies initially, in areas including banking-as-a-service, payments, insurtech, asset management and infrastructure. To date, Element has backed companies including embedded insurance platform Hepster, B2B payment network Billhop and cryptocurrency recovery service Coincover.

Headline Asia will close its fourth fund with over $100 million in commitments. In May, Infinity Ventures and e.ventures rebranded as Headline Asia, which focuses on global early-stage investments in e-commerce, logistics and fintech.

People

Felicis Ventures hired Jake Storm as vice president. He was previously an investor at IVP. Felicis recently participated in funding rounds for employee-engagement and performance-management technology provider Culture Amp and software security startup r2c.

Instabase, which helps automate end-to-end business processes and workflows, appointed Nathaniel Crook as chief revenue officer. He was most recently global vice president of strategic accounts and partnerships at Microsoft. San Francisco-based Instabase is backed by investors including Greylock Partners , New Enterprise Associates , Andreessen Horowitz , Index Ventures and Spark Capital.

Exits

Social media management provider Hootsuite Inc . purchased Heyday, a conversational AI platform for personalized customer experiences, for 60 million Canadian dollars ($48 million). Vancouver-based Hootsuite is backed by investors including Accel, Salesforce Ventures , Insight Partners and Fidelity Investments.

Instawork, a staffing service for hourly workers, acquired recruiting platform Drafted for an undisclosed amount. Craft Ventures led Instawork's recent $60 million Series C round, which included participation from Greylock, Benchmark, Spark Capital, GV and others. Drafted was a portfolio company of Afore Capital, NextGen Venture Partners and UpVentures.

Blockchain technology startup Figure Technologies Inc. agreed to merge with mortgage lender Homebridge Financial Services . Earlier this year, Figure raised a $200 million Series D round at a $3.2 billion valuation. Investors included 10T Holdings, DCM, Digital Currency Group , HCM Capital, Ribbit Capital and RPM Ventures.

New Money

Rapyd, a London-based company offering digital payments software, raised $300 million in Series E funding led by Target Global. New investors including funds managed by Fidelity Management & Research Co ., Altimeter Capital, Whale Rock Capital, BlackRock and Dragoneer Investment Group also contributed to the round, along with existing backers General Catalyst, Latitude, Durable Capital Partners, Tal Capital, Avid Ventures and Spark Capital. Earlier this year, Rapyd acquired Icelandic payments services company Valitor for $100 million.

Nozomi Networks Inc ., a San Francisco- and Switzerland-based industrial cybersecurity provider, scored $100 million in Series D funding. Triangle Peak Partners led the round, which included participation from Forward Investments, Honeywell Ventures, In-Q-Tel , Keysight Technologies , Porsche Ventures and Telefónica Ventures.

WorkJam, a Montreal-based digital workplace platform, secured $35 million in growth financing from Silver Lake. The company recently appointed Daniel Crepeau as chief operating officer and Rich Halbert as chief strategy officer.

Finite State, a Columbus, Ohio-based connected device security provider, secured $30 million in Series B financing. Energize Ventures led the round, which saw participation from Schneider Electric Ventures and Merlin Ventures .

Plant Prefab, a Rialto, Calif.-based prefabricated home builder, landed $30 million in Series B funding. Asahi Kasei Corp . and Paris Ventures co-led the investment, which included additional support from Amazon Alexa Fund, Ferguson Ventures and Obvious Ventures. As part of the round, Western Technology Investments and ATEL Capital Group provided venture debt and equipment financing.

G2 Venture Partners is leading a $25 million Series B funding round for MakerSights, a software provider that helps retailers create and manage their product assortments with an eye toward reducing waste. The new round also includes participation from new investors Golub Capital and Gaingels as well as existing backers Forerunner Ventures , which led an $8.5 million Series A round in 2019, and Baseline Ventures , which led a $3.1 million seed funding round in 2017.

ZeroEyes Inc., a weapons detection startup, snagged $20.9 million in Series A funding. Led by Octave Ventures, the round included participation from Legion Capital, Grateful Investments, Alliance Holdings and Alpha Intelligence Capital.

Yaydoo, a Mexico-based business-to-business software and payments provider, closed a $20.4 million Series A round. Base10 Partners and Monashees led the funding, which included contributions from SoftBank Latin America Fund and Leap Global Partners.

Banyan, a Holmdel, N.J.-based startup whose technology enables consumers to connect their receipts to any app, nabbed a $10 million Series A investment led by Fin Venture Capital.

Carbon Clean, a London-based carbon dioxide capture and separation technology developer, fetched $8 million in funding from Cemex, Equinor Ventures, ICOS Capital and WAVE Equity Partners.
